metadata.titleEn: Mineral content, chemical composition, temperature and pressure estimates of Langshan lherzolite xenoliths in northwestern North China
metadata.description: This data is the estimation of mineral content, major and trace element composition of mantle peridotite, and the estimation of temperature and pressure of peridotite. The sample is lherzolite from basalt in Langshan area, northwest of North China Craton in 2019. The mineral content of peridotite was estimated by binocular microscope. The data of major and trace elements were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The estimated data of temperature and pressure of peridotite are calculated by mineral thermobarometer. The obtained data can reveal the lithospheric mantle properties and metasomatic process in northwest North China, and provide evidence for the lithospheric property transition and structural system transition in northwest North China.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "minabun" represents the mineral content estimation. The name of the file "minmajtra. XLS" represents the composition data of major and trace elements of minerals. The data sheet of major and trace elements of minerals contains major and trace elements of standard sample, olivine, orthopyroxene, clinopyroxene and spinel. The name of the file "PT" represents the estimated data of temperature and pressure.

literatureList.titleEn: Fertile lithospheric mantle underlying ancient continental crust beneath the northwestern North China craton: Significant effect from the southward subduction of the Paleo–Asian Ocean
literatureList.referenceEn: Dai, H.K., Zheng, J.P., Xiong, Q., Su, Y.P., Pan, S.K., Ping, X.Q., & Zhou, X. (2019). Fertile lithospheric mantle underlying ancient continental crust beneath the northwestern North China craton: Significant effect from the southward subduction of the Paleo–Asian Ocean. Geological Society of American Bulletin,  131(1-2), 3-20.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate mineral content and chemical composition in mantle peridotite xenoliths?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to estimate mineral content in mantle peridotite xenoliths is utilizing a binocular microscope. For chemical composition, both major and trace elements of minerals are analyzed using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS).

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to estimate mineral content and chemical composition in mantle peridotite xenoliths?
Feature Specification.Answer: binocular microscope, laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, mineral thermobarometry

Interpretation.Question: What inferences can be made about the lithospheric mantle properties and metasomatic processes in the northwestern part of the North China Craton based on the mineral content and chemical composition data collected from spinel lherzolite xenoliths?
Interpretation.Answer: The mineral content and chemical composition data, along with temperature and pressure estimates, can reveal characteristics of the lithospheric mantle such as its composition, thermal state, and the extent of any metasomatic processes that have occurred. These insights can contribute to understanding the transition in lithospheric properties and tectonic regime changes in the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes inaccuracies in estimating mineral contents and chemical compositions in mantle peridotites?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inaccuracies in estimating mineral contents and chemical compositions in mantle peridotites can be caused by limitations in the analysis techniques used, such as the precision of the binocular microscope for mineral content estimation and the accuracy of the laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for analyzing major and trace elements. Additionally, the variability in sample collection conditions and the inherent heterogeneity of the mantle peridotite samples can contribute to estimation errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the understanding of lithospheric mantle properties when mineral content estimates and temperature-pressure calculations are derived from data collected using optical microscopes and laser ablation techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using optical microscopes to estimate mineral content and laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for elemental analysis allows for precise and detailed data collection. This approach can lead to a more accurate understanding of the lithospheric mantle properties and metasomatic processes in the northwest region of the North China Craton. The data may provide evidence for changes in lithospheric properties and tectonic regime shifts in the area.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting mineral content and chemical composition data for mantle peridotite xenoliths from the northwestern part of the North China Craton?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to reveal the properties and metasomatic processes of the lithospheric mantle in the northwestern part of the North China Craton, providing evidence for the transformation of the lithospheric properties and tectonic regime shifts in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in estimating mineral content and chemical composition of mantle peridotite xenoliths from a dataset collected in basalt regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The estimation of mineral content is performed using a binocular microscope. The chemical composition, including major and trace elements of the minerals, is analyzed through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Temperature and pressure estimations for the peridotite are calculated using mineral thermobarometers.
